awd_titl_txt: Cosmogenic surface exposure dating of Cordilleran-Laurentide ice-sheet separation during the last deglaciation: implications for abrupt sea-level rise
awd_abstract_narration:
The rise in sea level during the last deglaciation (21,000-6,000 years ago) was punctuated by intervals of abrupt sea-level rise, called meltwater pulses (MWP), which indicate the development of instability in one or more of Earth's ice sheets. The largest MWP, MWP-1A, occurred 14,600-14,300 years ago with ~14 m of global-mean sea-level rise. It was recently hypothesized that the collapse of an ice saddle between the Cordilleran (CIS) and Laurentide (LIS) ice sheets could have caused MWP-1A when the two ice sheets separated. Results from this research will provide important data on whether the ice sheet failure caused rapid jumps in sea level. Determining if the ice sheet separation caused a MWP will provide insight into the evolution of North Atlantic climate and its relationship to meltwater discharge to the Arctic Ocean where much of the ice sheet separation meltwater would be routed. These findings will also have implications for development of instability in the Greenland ice sheet as it has an ice saddle similar to the one previously seen in the Cordilleran-Laurentide. Finally, these results will date when an ice-free corridor formed between the Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets, which has important ramifications for human migration routes to the Americas. 

This project will date the end of CIS-LIS separation with 50 boulder cosmogenic surface exposure ages at six locations along the suture zone of the ice sheets between 50°N and 60°N. These ages will determine when CIS-LIS separation was complete, and if it was concurrent with MWP-1A or another interval of rapid sea-level rise. They will also document if CIS-LIS separation occur over centuries, which could cause a MWP, or over millennia which would be inconsistent with separation causing a MWP.

por.por_cntn:
During the peak of the last Ice Age, the Cordilleran (CIS) and Laurentide (LIS) Ice Sheets grew on North America and coalesced along an ~1500-km-long suture zone over the eastern foothills of the Canadian Rockies, constituting the largest ice mass and contributor to sea-level change on the planet. The rise in sea level following the peak of the last Ice Age was punctuated by intervals of abrupt sea-level rise, called meltwater pulses (MWP), which indicate the development of instability in one or more of Earth’s ice sheets that existed during that time. The largest MWP, MWP-1A, occurred 14,600-14,300 years ago (i.e., 14.6-14.3 ka) with ~14 m of global-mean sea-level rise. Ever since the identification of MWP-1A, its sources have been widely debated. Based on ice-sheet model simulations, it was recently hypothesized that the collapse of an ice saddle between the CIS and LIS could have caused MWP-1A when the two ice sheets separated. Separation of these ice sheets may also have been critical to providing a migration route for the first peopling of the Americas from Beringia down to the Great Plains through what is commonly referred to as the “Ice-Free Corridor” (IFC).  CIS-LIS separation is only poorly dated by minimum-limiting techniques, however, with the existing chronology placing CIS-LIS separation as occurring anywhere from ~14 ka to ~19 ka. This uncertainty in the age of ice-sheet separation is thus too large to test the hypotheses that it contributed to MWP-1A and that it was available as a migration route for the first peopling of the Americas.

The major goals of this project were to directly date CIS-LIS separation to determine if this occurred coincident with or before MWP-1A, and to document if separation progressed at a rate commensurate with a MWP. At the same time, dating ice-sheet separation provides direct information on the age of the IFC, thus allowing an assessment of its availability as a migration route for the first peopling of the Americas.

To address these questions, we directly dated the end of CIS-LIS separation with 10Be surface exposure ages obtained on samples of 64 glacial boulders at six locations along the suture zone of the ice sheets between 50°N and 60°N. Our research objectives are readily answerable with our 10Be ages because we are able to achieve centennial precision with 10Be dating of glacial boulders that became exposed to cosmic rays following deglaciation. If CIS-LIS separation was complete by ~14.0 ka, then it likely supplied meltwater to MWP-1A, while at the same time, the IFC had not opened in time to provide a migration route for the first peopling of the Americas. Alternatively, these ages may place the end of separation earlier, potentially concurrent with a MWP at ~19 ka and thus making it available as a migration route. Furthermore, if final separation progressed from our southern and northern sample sites to our central sites in centuries, then this rate is commensurate with the rate required to cause a MWP. If, however, it took >1 ka for CIS-LIS separation to complete, then this likely did not cause a MWP even if the end of separation was concurrent with a MWP.

Our new 10Be ages from our southernmost site at 50.0°N indicate that Cordilleran-Laurentide Ice-Sheet separation was underway at 15.4±0.4 ka while ice-sheet separation at 52.2°N occurred 14.8±0.3 ka. Ages from our two northern sites date ice-sheet separation at 14.5±0.5 ka and 14.4±0.2 ka, respectively. Finally, the center of the suture zone between 53.9°N and 56.1°N deglaciated at 14.2±0.3 ka and 13.8±0.1 ka, respectively. These new 10Be ages show that ice-sheet separation, and by extension the saddle collapse, occurred over at least 1 to 2 millennia. This largely rules out greater saddle-collapse contributions to MWP-1A, which could have potentially happened if the collapse instead occurred over a few centuries. Our 10Be ages also date ice-sheet separation in the southernmost sector beginning by ~15.4 ka, which means that the saddle collapse was not triggered by the Bølling warming at ~14.7 ka. Finally, our new 10Be chronology closely dates the final opening of the IFC as occurring at 13.8±0.5 ka, establishing that the IFC was not available as a migration route for the peopling of the Americas that had occurred before ~15.6 ka suggested by current archaeological and ancient genomic evidence. 

Results will be disseminated to the scientific community through publications and presentations at international meetings. Results and their implications will be presented to the lay public through grade school education programs and public lectures at Burpee Museum of Natural History in Rockford, IL, which will focus on CIS-LIS history, and its relationship to climate and the peopling of the Americas, through web outreach to other museums, and through the Ice Age Flood Institute. We expect that results will also be incorporated into popular science pieces.
